comments:
If one closes a project, editors for some resources of this project are still open, and one stops and starts eclipse, eclipse hangs during the start up process.
at
http://howardlewisship.com/blog/2004/10/worst-eclipse-crash-ever.html
I found a solution to get my eclipse running again.

I wanted to write a reproducable description without using any extensions, but the generic editor closes itself if the project of the related resource gets closed. Some Extensions, like pydev, do ignore any events that might be thrown in such an event. I will submit a separate bug entry for that extension, but I believe eclipse should be forgiving with extensions, and also catch that exception, and not open the file again. 
This is my stack trace, you can reproduce it by:
1. Installing pydev (Sorry for needing an extension)
2. Creating a new project
3. Creating a new python file in this project
4. Closing the project
5. Stopping eclipse
6. Trying to start eclipse

This was tested with above given Eclipse version, and pydev 1.2.5.

!MESSAGE Resource /powerpoint is not open.

Warning, the solution in the url works only once. The second time, these files do not exist any more, and you are screwed. Like me. Never delete files if you don't know what you are doing :-)
Does this happen without the python plug-in? The stack trace looks like a bug in that editor implementation.

No, it does not happen without the python plug in.
It looks like the pydev plugin does not react on the information that a project got closed. Thus does not close its python editor views, and on restarting, it is not possible to restart the editor view, and eclipse just stops.
While searching for similar problems it seems some cobol extensions can do the same harm.

What I would like to see is that eclipse stays defensive and does catch the exception that a Resource is not available and would stop trying to open the editor. So that an extension can not kill eclipse.
Yes it would also good if pydev would implement an action for it. I am diving into it too, but I am very slow, as currently my eclipse doesn't work any longer ;-)
Maybe I should shift my focus to solve this bug before I try to add the action handling in pydev...

best regards and thanks in advance.
Renaming to reflect Eclipse side of the issue
Just as a note... the new version of pydev already fixes it.
